C++ - file structure

  • File organization example
  • References

  1. C++ File Structure

    C++ does not have strict rules for organizing source files. The source files can be typically divided into two categories, declaration files (.h) and implementation files (.cpp) Different from Java that puts declaration and implementation together and the file name must be the public class's name, the class name, .h file name and .cpp file name can be totally different. Moreover, one definition file can contain more than one class's definitions and be implemented by several source files. (One source file can even just have one function implemented). Also, one .cpp file can implement several .h files.

    The .cpp files is binded to .h files by #include directive. The implementation function is connected to function declaration by Class:: symbol.

    The .h file also can contain the implementation. This is actually a feature of inline function. This implementation is treated as inline function and the inline keyword is added by default when ignored.

    The .cpp file can contain class declaration: but treat an an java private. and must be implemented here.

    Term

    • driver file: The .cpp file contains the main function, which is the entry point for this program.
    • definition (implmentation):
    • declaration:
